Peter, yes, that is another way that it could be done that I forgot to
ment=
ion:  You could characterize species by some kind of consolidated
statistic=
 like their mean weights on shared dimensions or something
like that.  It m=
ay again lead to some kind of stability, or maybe it
has another benefit.  =
It does seem more principled in terms of
characterizing what a species is. =
 

However, I am not sure if it would have any benefit towards
performance,=
 which is probably the most significant issue.  Although
it would make more=
 sense in principle, it may simply not be as good as
forcing species to clu=
ster around their champions.  It is an empirical
issue and I do not know th=
e answer to it.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <pe=
tar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi Ken, 
> 
> > My implementation currently =
chooses a single representative of each
> > species and new individuals in =
the population are compared with the
> > list of representatives in order. =
 The new individual is placed in 
> the
> > first species with a representa=
tive that is within the compatibility
> > distance.  
> > 
> > One other th=
ing some people don't realize is that my implementation
> > sorts the genom=
es in each species in order of their fitness, which
> > means ultimately th=
at the representative becomes the individual with
> > highest fitness.
> > =

> 
> This issue is something I was thinking of very often. Because one 
> =
species can be defined as a group of genomes that have many matching 
> gen=
es close to each other (with respect to the global compatibility
threshold)=
, it is possible that the representative of a species could 
> be kind of g=
eneralized data across all members of the species, not 
> just one genome. =

> 
> For example, the representative can be recomputed every generation, i=
n 
> a process where all members mate into one single individual which 
> b=
ecomes the representative of the species. All genes should be allowed 
> to=
 be inherited in an iterative process resulting in a genome that 
> carries=
 all complexity of all individuals of the species. Can this be 
> considere=
d a good representative? Or maybe just regular mating, where 
> excess/disj=
oint genes are inherited from more fit members. I don't 
> know what effect=
 this could have. And it is important that the weights 
> of matching genes=
 should be averaged during mating.
> 
> The idea is that the representative=
 of a species can be not just a 
> genome that is existing as a member, but=
 a special genome that is only 
> used during clustering, as the "overall p=
icture" of genetic distance. 
> 
> Does it make sense? 
> 
> Peter
>
